H+/1mmol. ω-Sulfonic-perfluoroalkylated poly(styrene–maleic anhydride)/silica hybridized nanocomposite as a new kind of solid acid catalyst Zhenghuan Lin a b Limei Huang a Qidan Ling a c ⁎ Hong Chen a Chengxue Zhao b ⁎ a College of Materials Science and Engineering, Fujian Normal University, Fuzhou 350007, China b Department of Chemistry, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China c Fujian Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials, Fuzhou 350007, Fujian, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 21 54709629; fax: +86 21 54741297. Graphical abstract Highlights ► The nanocomposite (FSMA/SiO2) bearing mixed acids was synthesized in mild condition. ► FSMA resin was uniformly distributed in silica framework through covalent linkage. ► The acidic amount and pore structure of FSMA/SiO2 are adjusted simultaneously. ► The acidity of FSMA/SiO2 is easily regulated for various catalytic processes. ► FSMA/SiO2 has showed high activity in cyclization, condensation and esterification. A new kind of ω-sulfonic-perfluoroalkylated poly(styrene–maleic anhydride)/silica hybrid nanocomposite FSMA/SiO2 has been synthesized under mild conditions by perfluoroalkylation of styrene–maleic anhydride copolymer (SMA) with ω-fluorosulfonylperfluorodiacyl peroxides (SFAP), and followed in turn by aminolysis using (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES), alkali hydrolysis, gelation with tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) and finally acidification. The hybrid solid acid FSMA/SiO2 with terminal perfluoroalkylsulfonic and carboxyl groups was characterized by FTIR, SEM, TEM, TGA, XPS, EDX, acidimetry and nitrogen sorption technique. Its pore structure, acid strength and acid amount were easily modulated by controlling the gelation and perfluoroalkylation conditions. The catalytic activity and selectivity, as well as reusability of FSMA/SiO2 were tested in three important reactions, namely, cyclization of pseudoionone, condensation of indole and esterification of benzoic acid. Owing to the higher exchange capacity than that of Nafion/SiO2, and the stronger acidity than that of Amberlyst-15, the nanocomposite FSMA/SiO2 showed higher activity and selectivity than these commercial solid acids in the reactions. Keywords Solid acid Sol–gel Nanocomposite Perfluoroalkanesulfonic Superacidity 1 Introduction Organic/inorganic hybrid materials, a kind of composite, offer the combinations of the advantages of both organic and inorganic components such as good mechanical strength, high thermostability, easy processability and low cost [1–7]. For allowing designing and controlling the structure in molecular level, hybrid materials are easily functionalized and widely applied in optics [8,9], electronic devices [10–12], photochrism [13,14], medicine [15], separation [16] and catalysis [4,17]. Traditional methods are difficult to prepare organic/inorganic hybrid materials for the different nature of two components. Sol–gel technique becomes one of the important ways to synthesize hybridized materials for its unique advantages: easy operation, mild reaction condition, high purity of products, diverse material shape molded for different applications [18–23]. Cation-exchange resins with strong acidity have been widely used as solid acid catalysts in organic reactions, including alkylation, transalkylation, isomerization, oligomerization, acylation, esterification and nitration, etc. [24–32]. There are two main classes of commercial strong-acid resin: nonfluorinated resin such as Amberlyst-15 and perfluoroalkylsulfonic resin such as Nafion NR50. The superacidity (H 0 =∼−12) and high thermostability (stable up to 280°C) of Nafion resins enable them to effectively catalyze alkylation of benzene, isomerization, and some select acylation [27]. However, Nafion NR50 is a kind of gel-type cation-exchange resin that does not swell in non-polar solvents. This makes its catalytic activity low in the reactions employing non-polar solvents due to the low accessibility of acid sites. To improve the surface area and the accessibility of acid sites, sulfonic resins were introduced into the silica skeleton to produce organic/inorganic hybrid composites [33–42]. For example, Harmer et al. employed sol–gel technique to prepare Nafion resin/silica nanocomposite (Nafion/SiO2) with surface area in the range of 50–500m2/g which is 1000 times higher than that of Nafion NR50 [33]. However, Nafion resin particles were entrapped within the porous silica network to produce Nafion/SiO2 hybrid composite without covalent linkage between organic and inorganic phase. Due to the aggregation of Nafion resin, the organic particles could not disperse uniformly in the silica framework, which made catalytic process complex [43]. In this work, we have developed a kind of ω-sulfonic-perfluoroalkylated poly(styrene–maleic anhydride)/silica hybridized nanocomposites (FSMA/SiO2) originated from SMA in mild condition. FSMA/SiO2 containing both perfluoroalkanesulfonic acid and carboxyl acid was synthesized by sol–gel method with covalent bond linkage between organic and inorganic phases. FSMA/SiO2 was characterized by FTIR, XPS, TGA, SEM, TEM, EDX, nitrogen sorption technique and acidimetry, and its catalytic activity as solid acid in the cyclization of pseudoionone, the condensation of indole, and esterification of benzoic acid was also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 General information BET surface area, pore diameter and BJH cumulative pore volume were obtained using a Micromeritics instrument (ASAP Micromeritics 2000). The morphological characteristics were observed with a SEM (Philips Sirion 200) and a TEM (JEM-2010). XPS spectra were obtained on an Omicron ESCA spectrometer. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) using the KBr pellet was carried out on a Perkin–Elmer 930 spectrometer. The thermogravimetric studies were performed on a TGA 7 (Perkin–Elmer). Exchange capacity was determined by acidimetry. Nuclear magnetic resonance was performed using Varian Mercury 400 spectrometer using CDCl3 as the solvent. Microanalyses were completed on a VARIO EL III elemental analyzer. SMA containing 12mol% of maleic anhydride was obtained from Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology (SRIPT). The solution of SFAP in F113 (CCl2FCClF2) was synthesized by following the reported procedure [44] and kept under a freezing condition before use. Other reagents were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. and used as received. Amberlyst-15, Amberlyst-36 and Nafion NR50 were purchased from Aldrich. The commercial catalysts and Nafion/SiO2 prepared according to the reported method [33] were dried at 60°C under vacuum overnight before use. 2.2 Synthesis of FSMA/SiO2 SMA (0.75g, 7.3mmol) was dissolved in 5mL of dichloromethane, purging with nitrogen for 0.5h. Cooling to 0°C, F113 solution (0.4M) of SFAP (9mL, 3.6mmol) was added to the SMA solution under stirring. After 40h, the solution was washed with water and dried under vacuum to obtain perfluoroalkylated poly(styrene–maleic anhydride) FSMA. 19F NMR (CDCl3, 400MHz) of FSMA: δ −56.6 (1F, CFO), −38.9 (2F, CF2 S), −10.4 (3F,CF3), −5.3 to −2.4 (2F, OCF2), 118.4 (1F,SO2F). To a solution of FSMA in 7mL of THF, (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (0.06g, 0.29mmol) was added at room temperature and stirred for 0.5h. Then, the solution was added to 15mL of 5% aqueous NaOH solution and stirred for 5h at 30°C followed by neutralization with HCl. The hydrolyzed FSMA solution was kept in the freezer. In a beaker (150mL) was added TEOS (17.2g, 80mmol), water (1.8mL) and 0.2N aqueous HCl (4.1mL). The mixture was stirred for 3h at room temperature and added to the hydrolyzed FSMA solution. After stirring for 15min, 30mL of 2.6N ammonia water was rapidly added to the solution. Within 20s with shaking, the mixed solutions gelled to form a hard solid. The solid gel was dried at 90°C for 24h, acidified with 6N aqueous HCl (30mL) for 36h, washed down residue HCl with water to neutral and then dried at 80°C under vacuum to a constant weight of FSMA/SiO2. 2.3 Catalysis studies Cyclization of pseudoionone was carried out in a two-necked flask. To a solution of pseudoionone (0.2mL) in cyclohexane (5mL), a solid catalyst (0.1g) was added under stirring at 80°C. Unreacted pseudoionone and main products were determined by an Agilent 6890N GC equipped with a FID detector. In condensation of indole with acetone, to 10mol% catalyst (catalyst/acetone=0.1mequiv. H+/1mmol) was added indole (2.0mmol), acetone (1.0mmol) and 5mL of CH2Cl2 as solvent. Then the mixture was stirred for 12h at room temperature. The catalyst was filtered and washed with ethanol three times. The combined solution was evaporated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified via column chromatography (silica gel, petroleum ether:ethyl acetate=4:1) to give dimethyl diindolylmethane: 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400MHz), δ 1.91 (s, 6H), 6.87 (t, 2H), 7.02 (m, 2H), 7.07 (t, 2H), 7.28 (d, 2H), 7.40 (d, 2H), 7.85 (brs, 2H); IR (KBr) ν (cm−1), 3440, 2964, 2859, 1659, 1384, 734. The esterification of benzoic acid was investigated in a 25mL round flask. To the flask was added benzoic acid (0.24g, 2mmol), n-butanol (0.44g, 6mmol) and solid catalyst (catalyst/benzoic acid=0.1mequiv. H+/1mmol) in turn. The mixture was stirred at 115°C for 6h, filtered and washed with ethyl acetate for three times, and then evaporated under vacuum. The conversion of benzoic acid was obtained from the amount of unreactive benzoic acid detected by column chromatography. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and physical characterization Through five-step reactions, namely, perfluoroalkylation, aminolysis, hydrolysis, co-gelation and acidification, the target nanocomposite FSMA/SiO2 was synthesized (Scheme 1 ). The perfluoroalkylation of SMA with FSAP was induced via single electron-transfer (SET) process [45] including a de-electronation of phenyl ring to yield cation radical, combination of the cation radical with perfluoroalkane radical to form δ-complex, and deprotonation of the complex to give ω-fluorosulfonylperfluoroalkylated poly(styrene–maleic anhydride) (FSMA). FSMA was further functionalized by aminolysis of maleic anhydride in SMA with coupling regent APTES. In this step, the loading of APTES had to be controlled to avoid the gelation in the following hydrolysis under NaOH. Followed by alkali hydrolysis, gelation with TEOS and acidification in HCl, the FSMA/SiO2 was finally obtained. The FTIR spectra of SMA (a), FSMA (b), FSMA/SiO2 (c) and SiO2 (d) are shown in Fig. 1 . The plot of FSMA shows strong bands characteristic of the perfluoroalkane group: ν (CF3) at 1310cm−1, ν (CF2) at 1227cm−1. The peak at 814cm−1 characteristic of a para-disubstituted phenyl ring, as well as carbonyl absorption, provides strong evidence for para-ω-fluorosulfonylperfluoroalkylation of SMA. The FTIR spectrum of FSMA/SiO2 shows similar peaks as that of SiO2 for the high amount of SiO2 in the hybrid materials. Fig. 2 shows TGA plot of SMA and FSMA/SiO2 under heating at 10°C/min from room temperature up to about 800°C. In the plot of SMA, The less than 5% weight loss before 150°C is due to residual moisture, and the loss (more than 93%) at 390°C is resulted from polymer decomposition. In the plot of FSMA/SiO2, there is a new loss at 283°C before 400°C, which is caused by desulfonation of perfluoroalkanesulfonic acid. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were employed to analyzing the composition and distribution of the element in the surface of FSMA/SiO2. As shown in XPS spectra (Fig. 3 ) of FSMA/SiO2, there are five kinds of element detected in the surface of the nanocomposites with F1s at 688.8eV, O1s at 533.1eV, C1s at 285.3eV, Si2p at 103.1eV, and N1s at 400.1eV. S element is not found in XPS spectrum for its low amount. A similar result is exhibited in the EDX spectrum (Fig. 4 ) of FSMA/SiO2 except for a weak peak of S element. Element mapping of FSMA/SiO2 shown in Fig. 5 proves a uniform F, O, and Si distribution across the surface of nanocomposites. The distribution density of F is less than that of O and Si for its low amount in the FSMA/SiO2. 3.2 Pore structure and its controlling The microstructure and morphology of hybrid materials have been investigated by using SEM and TEM. The SEM photo (Fig. 6 ) at 200,000-fold magnification exhibits that the microstructure of FSMA/SiO2 is irregularly particulate in nature with primary particles in the range of 10–30nm, and that there are plenty of complex pores between particles with primary pores in the range of 2–20nm. The TEM image (see Supporting information, Fig. S1) of FSMA/SiO2 also shows irregular-shaped particles and porosity. Nitrogen sorption technique analysis of FSMA/SiO2 gave the porosity with 221m2/g of BET surface area, 0.77cm3/g of BJH pore volume and 11.3nm of BJH pore diameter which is consistent with the result of SEM. The isotherm plot and pore size distribution of are shown in Fig. S2 and S3 (see Supporting information). Like Nafion/SiO2, the pore structure of FSMA/SiO2 could be controlled by varying the sol–gel conditions, such as the concentration of alkali and the amount of the organic phase. As shown in Table 1 , the alkali (aqueous ammonia) concentration imposes great effects on all of the pore structure parameters (Entries 1–3). With the increase in concentration of alkali, the surface area of FSMA/SiO2 decreases dramatically, while pore volume and diameter increase observably. The effect of the concentration of alkali on adsorption isotherm and pore size distribution of FSMA/SiO2 was also investigated (see Supporting information, Fig. S4 and S5). It is found that using higher alkali concentration make the adsorption amount at the low pressure turn less and pore size distribution shift to the right, which indicates that the amount of micropore in composite becomes less, resulting in larger average pore diameter. When the molar ratio between SFAP and SMA rises from 1:10 to 1:1 (Entries 3 and 4) causing the increase in the content of organic resin, surface area and pore volume of FSMA/SiO2 decrease, and its pore diameter changes a little. These results keep consistent with that of Nafion/SiO2 [33]. 3.3 The adjustment on exchange capacity of FSMA/SiO2 There are two kinds of acidic groups in FSMA/SiO2. One is perfluoroalkanesulfonic acid (RfSO3H) originated from the perfluoroalkylation of styrene with SFAP. The other is carboxyl acid (CO2H) derived from the hydrolysis and aminolysis of maleic anhydride. The total amount of the two acids determines the exchange capacity of FSMA/SiO2. Therefore, the exchange capacity can be easily adjusted through changing the using amount of SFAP or the concentration of maleic anhydride in SMA, instead of varying the content of polymer resin in the composites, which would simultaneously change the porosity of composites. For instance, the surface area of Nafion/SiO2 dropped rapidly at high loading of Nafion resin (such as 60wt%) [33]. In this work, we have investigated the effect of molar ratio between SFAP and SMA on the exchange capacity of FSMA/SiO2 with the results shown in the Table 2 . The amount of RfSO3H in FSMA/SiO2 could be calculated from the content of F obtained from elemental analysis. With the increase in molar ratio between SFAP and SMA, the loading of RfSO3H in FSMA/SiO2 increase, reaching 0.2mmol/g (Entry 4) at the molar ratio of 1:1 (SFAP:SMA). From the molar ratio between SMA and APTES, the amount of CO2H could be calculated to be 0.25mmol/g. Thus, the total exchange capacity of FSMA/SiO2 should be 0.45mmol/g. However, the acidimetry gives the exchange capacity of 0.35mmol/g, which shows maleic anhydride was not hydrolyzed completely. From the measured exchange capacity of FSMA/SiO2, it can be deduced that the actual amount of CO2H is approximately 0.15mmol/g. Through change the molar ratio of SFAP and SMA, the loading ratio between RfSO3H and CO2H in FSMA/SiO2 is regulated from 1:3 to 1:0.8 with the exchange capacity adjusted from 0.19 to 0.35mmol/g. 3.4 Cyclization of pseudoionone The cyclization of pseudoionone (Scheme 2 ) was investigated with the FSMA/SiO2 nanocomposite. The conversion of pseudoionone and yield of ionone under FSMA/SiO2 are given in Table 3 with a comparison with the results by using Amberlyst-15, Amberlyst-36, Nafion NR50 and Nafion/SiO2. All of the catalysts containing RfSO3H (Entries 3–5) show good activity and selectivity except for Nafion NR50 because of its low surface area. Their excellent activity is attributed to their super-strong acidity of perfluoroalkanesulfonic acid group (RfSO3H). It is believed that their good selectivity is also ascribed to the bulky, lipophilic and flexible perfluoroalkyl side chain with ether linkage [46]. Due to higher surface area and more easily accessible acid sites, nanocomposites Nafion/SiO2 and FSMA/SiO2 exhibit higher yield than pure polymer catalysts. It took FSMA/SiO2 1h to yield 62% of α-ionone with quantitative conversion and 100% selectivity. In addition, we have tested the reusability of FSMA/SiO2 in the cyclization. FSMA/SiO2 recovered by simply washing with ethanol and drying was reused under the same conditions. In the five runs, FSMA/SiO2 showed high activity with the conversion of pseudoionone kept at 100%. In the sixth run, a slight deactivation took place with 93% of conversion. The result indicates good reusability of FSMA/SiO2 in the reaction. 3.5 Condensation of indole Diindolylmethane is a kind of compounds with health-promoting properties which arise from a beneficial shift in the balance of the sex hormones, estrogen and testosterone. Traditionally, diindolylmethane can be synthesized by condensation of indoles with carbonyl compounds. The condensation of indole with aldehyde was effectively catalyzed by solid acids to give hexyl diindolylmethanes [47]. However, the activity of the condensation of indole with ketone is lower than with aldehyde for its higher steric hindrance. Here, hybrid nanocomposites and pure polymer resins were employed to catalyze condensation of indole with acetone to produce dimethyl diindolylmethane (Scheme 3 ). The results are shown in the Table 4 . Fluorinated sulfonic resin FPS [48] (Entry 3) with RfSO3H exhibits best catalytic activity in polymer resins for being of the advantages of both Amberlyst-15 and Nafion NR50 resins such as big surface area and superacidity. However, the yield of diindolylmethane is not yet high at 10mol% of FPS loading. Obviously, the catalytic activity of nanocomposites is much higher than that of pure polymer resins for easy accessibility of acid sites with 71% of yield at 5mol% of loading. 3.6 Esterification of benzoic acid The esterification of benzoic acid with n-butanol (Scheme 4 ) was investigated with FSMA/SiO2, Amberlyst-15, Amberlyst-36, Nafion NR50 and its nanocomposites Nafion/SiO2. Table 5 gives the conversion of benzoic acid under these solid acids. Since the esterification can smoothly proceed under strong acid, Amberlyst-15 behaves good activity in pure polymer catalysts with 69% of conversion of benzoic acid. It is found that the conversion of benzoic acid under hybrid nanocomposites (Entries 4 and 5) is higher than under Amberlyst-15 owing to big surface area and easy accessibility of acidic sites, reaching 81% under Nafion/SiO2 and 87% under FSMA/SiO2, respectively. 4 Conclusions Via perfluoroalkylation of styrene–maleic anhydride copolymer with ω-fluorosulfonylperfluorodiacyl peroxides followed by aminolysis with (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane, alkali hydrolysis, gelation using tetraethoxysilane and acidification in aqueous HCl, we have developed a new kind of ω-sulfonic-perfluoroalkylated poly(styrene–maleic anhydride)/silica hybrid nanocomposites FSMA/SiO2 bearing perfluoroalkylsulfonic and carboxyl terminal groups. Compared to Nafion/SiO2, FSMA/SiO2 has advantages in low cost, mild synthetic conditions, high exchange capacity, homodispersity of the resin in silica, adjustable acidity and easy functionalization. The nanocomposite FSMA/SiO2 showed higher activity and better selectivity than the widely used commercial solid acids catalysts such as Nafion and Amberlyst-15 in the synthesis of ionone (cyclization), dimethyl diindolylmethane (condensation) and butyl benzoate (esterification). The further studies via tailoring FSMA/SiO2 nanocomposite by varying its acid strength and content for particular reactions, are under the way. coredata.dc:description: A new kind of ω-sulfonic-perfluoroalkylated poly(styrene–maleic anhydride)/silica hybrid nanocomposite FSMA/SiO2 has been synthesized under mild conditions by perfluoroalkylation of styrene–maleic anhydride copolymer (SMA) with ω-fluorosulfonylperfluorodiacyl peroxides (SFAP), and followed in turn by aminolysis using (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES), alkali hydrolysis, gelation with tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) and finally acidification. The hybrid solid acid FSMA/SiO2 with terminal perfluoroalkylsulfonic and carboxyl groups was characterized by FTIR, SEM, TEM, TGA, XPS, EDX, acidimetry and nitrogen sorption technique. Its pore structure, acid strength and acid amount were easily modulated by controlling the gelation and perfluoroalkylation conditions. The catalytic activity and selectivity, as well as reusability of FSMA/SiO2 were tested in three important reactions, namely, cyclization of pseudoionone, condensation of indole and esterification of benzoic acid. Owing to the higher exchange capacity than that of Nafion/SiO2, and the stronger acidity than that of Amberlyst-15, the nanocomposite FSMA/SiO2 showed higher activity and selectivity than these commercial solid acids in the reactions.
coredata.dc:title: ω-Sulfonic-perfluoroalkylated poly(styrene–maleic anhydride)/silica hybridized nanocomposite as a new kind of solid acid catalyst
